articles.title: Georgia Voter Information Page Experiences Glitch During Primary Election
articles.content:
The My Voter Page, run by the Georgia Secretary of State's Office, experienced an unexpected glitch during Tuesday's primary election, leaving voters without access to their registration status and precinct location for about an hour. The site, which allows users to track their absentee ballots and view sample ballots, was unavailable between 1-2 pm due to a surge in traffic.

The issue was attributed to the high volume of requests for specific information, such as downloading sample ballots, rather than simply viewing polling locations. "It's not just the user, it's the things they're requesting," said Gabriel Sterling, chief operating officer of the Georgia Secretary of State's Office. "When you're requesting to download a sample ballot, it's a lot more capacity than it is if you're just looking at your polling location."

The glitch has raised concerns about the site's ability to handle increased traffic during the November general election. Stephanie Ali, policy director with the voting rights group New Georgia Project, emphasized the importance of ensuring the site can handle the higher volume of users. "We have to have our confidence that this is getting fixed, that this is going to be stronger and that this is going to handle a higher volume going into November and frankly beyond," she said.

The issue was particularly concerning for absentee voters, who were advised to check the MVP for the status of their ballot and vote in person if it wasn't showing a confirmed delivery. The page's unavailability during peak hours could have caused significant issues for these voters.

While the site was eventually restored around 2 pm, the incident has raised questions about the preparedness of election officials for November's general election. "If this number of voters knocks it off its pedestal, then we've got to expect a higher number are coming and we've got to be ready for that," Ali said.

The glitch also highlighted ongoing delays at U.S. Postal Offices in Georgia, which risked the timely delivery of absentee ballots. The combination of these issues has led some to express concerns about the site's ability to handle increased traffic during peak election periods.

Despite the incident, election officials have vowed to take steps to ensure the site is prepared for the November general election. "We're going to be doing a lot of testing and making sure that our system can handle the volume we expect," said Sterling. With the stakes high for both political parties, ensuring the integrity and accessibility of Georgia's voter information page will be crucial in the coming months.

In the meantime, voters are encouraged to continue monitoring their registration status and absentee ballot tracking through the MVP site. While some may view this incident as a minor setback, it serves as a reminder of the importance of reliable election infrastructure and the need for continued vigilance in protecting the integrity of the voting process.

Georgia's primary election saw a roughly 20% voter turnout, with many voters taking advantage of early voting options. As the state prepares for November's general election, election officials must prioritize ensuring that the MVP site is ready to handle the increased traffic and demands of this critical election period.

articles.title: Preeclampsia Detection Test Offers New Hope for Pregnant Women in Georgia
articles.content:
Pre-eclampsia is a serious condition that affects up to 5% of pregnancies, typically occurring after 20 weeks' gestation. This potentially life-threatening condition can cause high blood pressure and lead to seizures, strokes, and heart disease later in life if left undetected. Fortunately, a new biomarker testing method has been approved by the FDA, offering healthcare providers a more accurate way to diagnose pre-eclampsia and provide optimal care for pregnant women.

According to Dr. Padmashree Chaudhury Woodham, Director of the Regional Prenatal Center at Wellstar Medical College of Georgia Health Center, this testing method can help determine the best possible outcome for patients. "This test is based on the levels of biomarkers that can help the provider really determine whether the patient needs to be an inpatient or outpatient, right? Do they need to stay in the hospital until their delivery or can they go home?" she explained.

The Georgia state government has taken notice of the importance of this testing method and has provided additional resources and funding to increase survival rates for pregnant women. In fact, more than $250,000 was allocated in the state budget this year, with a federal match also available.

One demographic that is disproportionately affected by pre-eclampsia is black women, who are up to five times more likely to experience this condition compared to other racial groups. Dr. Woodham urges women to discuss the test with their healthcare providers, as it is still relatively new and insurance companies may not yet be aware of its benefits.

The lack of maternal care resources in many Georgia counties has also been a significant issue. According to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), more than half of the state's counties are considered maternal care deserts. However, with this additional funding, healthcare providers can improve maternal outcomes in these areas.

Georgia had one of the highest rates of maternal deaths in the nation from 2018 to 2021, ranking seventh according to the CDC. The new biomarker testing method and increased resources could lead to a reduction in hospitalization rates and ultimately, maternal mortality rates over the next few years.

"This is going to improve the rates In terms of lower hospitalization, hopefully, over the next few years, we'll see lower rates of mortality as well as morbidity," Dr. Woodham concluded.

articles.title: Title: NTSB's Absence from Crash Scene Raises Questions
articles.content:
In the aftermath of a fatal plane crash in Buffalo, New York, on October 2, 2020, which claimed the lives of pilot Steve Barnes and his niece, questions have arisen regarding the National Transportation Safety Board's (NTSB) decision not to send an investigator to the scene. The NTSB, an independent federal agency responsible for investigating transportation accidents, determined that the probable cause of the crash was "the pilot's failure to maintain control of the airplane for undetermined reasons during the descent to the destination airport."

According to Ellen Sturm, Barnes' partner and the owner of the plane, the NTSB's decision not to send an investigator to the scene has left her feeling unsatisfied with the ultimate findings. She believes that there could have been something mechanically wrong with the plane, but since investigators did not examine it in person, they may have missed or mishandled crucial evidence.

The NTSB defended its decision, citing COVID-19 risks and stating that the data collected on scene and later was sufficient to determine the probable cause. However, Reps. Chris Jacobs (R) and Brian Higgins (D), who sent a letter to then-Chair Robert Sumwalt, urging the agency to travel to the scene, disagree.

The NTSB hired 57 new employees in fiscal year 2023, bringing its total staff to approximately 430, but current Chair Jennifer Homendy has stated that the agency is hoping to hire roughly 15 additional employees through 2027. The agency has also been criticized for not having enough resources to respond effectively to aviation crashes.

InvestigateTV and the Arnolt Center for Investigative Reporting conducted research on NTSB's on-scene response to aviation crashes, analyzing data from the CAROL database for all aviation events in the United States from January 1, 2015, through December 31, 2023. The study found that between January 1, 2015, and December 31, 2022, there were at least 15 instances where the NTSB did not send an investigator to the scene of a fatal crash.

The GAO report released in August 2023 highlighted the importance of the NTSB efficiently using its resources to deliver on its mission. "Identifying inefficiencies is key," said Heather Krause, managing director of GAO's physical infrastructure team and lead author of the report. "It could save lives. It could make the difference between finding safety flaws and not finding them."

In conclusion, while the NTSB has a crucial role in investigating transportation accidents, its decision not to send an investigator to the scene of a fatal plane crash raises questions about the effectiveness of its response. The agency's lack of resources and inefficiencies may hinder its ability to deliver on its mission, which could have significant consequences for public safety.

articles.title: Fatal Crash on I-75 Claims Four Lives, Leaves Community in Shock
articles.content:
A multi-car crash on Interstate 75 southbound in Bartow County near mile marker 286 left a devastating toll of four fatalities and six injuries Sunday night. According to eyewitnesses, the accident occurred when a Kia van veered off the roadway, crossed the median, and collided with several other vehicles.

"I was working at the Sunoco gas station just off I-75 when the crash happened," said Jessica Lopez, who witnessed the aftermath of the disaster. "Some people were upset because they were stuck in traffic, while others were crying. It was a chaotic scene."

The Georgia State Patrol has launched an investigation into the cause of the accident. Preliminary reports indicate that the Kia van was traveling northbound on I-75 when it left the roadway and entered the southbound lanes, causing the chain reaction.

Four people lost their lives in the crash: Dakarai Mason, 35; Erin Mason, 43; Brandon Crawford, 15; and Aimee Odom, 21. The victims included a civilian employee of the Holly Springs Police Department and a student at Kennesaw State University.

The news of the fatal crash has left the community stunned. "There aren't really words you can say to make anything better like that," Lopez said.

A social media post from the Holly Springs Police Department offered condolences to the family of Erin and Dakarai Mason, while Kennesaw State University confirmed Aimee Odom's death.

Bartow County schools also issued a statement asking for prayers and support for Brandon Crawford and his family. As the community struggles to come to terms with this tragedy, it is clear that the impact will be felt far beyond the immediate area affected by the crash.

articles.title: Georgia Ports Authority Sees Record-Breaking Automobile Shipments Amidst Baltimore Bridge Collapse
articles.content:
The Georgia Ports Authority has reported that April was its busiest month ever for automobile shipments, with the Port of Brunswick taking in thousands of additional car and truck imports that needed rerouting from Baltimore following its deadly bridge collapse. The second-busiest U.S. port for autos, Brunswick moved over 80,000 vehicles and heavy machinery units across its docks last month, a whopping 44% increase compared to April 2023.

The surge in shipments included over 9,000 automobile imports and 1,000 pieces of heavy machinery that were diverted from the Port of Baltimore, the nation's top auto port. Baltimore has been closed to most ships since the Francis Scott Key Bridge collapsed on March 26, killing six people, after a container ship crashed into one of its columns.

The Brunswick port, located 70 miles south of Savannah, had ample room to absorb the additional autos, said Griff Lynch, CEO of the Georgia Ports Authority. The agency's board is investing $262 million in upgrades and expansions to boost Brunswick's capacity. Completed projects include 80 acres of additional outdoor storage and 450,000 square feet of new warehouse space.

"We've expanded so much in Brunswick, I would say that it did not stretch us," Lynch said. "We've got a tremendous amount of capacity down there." The surge in auto shipments to Georgia is not solely attributed to the Baltimore shutdown, as Brunswick had its second-busiest month on record for autos and heavy machinery in March, which had mostly passed before the bridge collapse.

Auto shipments to Georgia have been booming since last year, when U.S. auto sales saw their biggest increase in a decade. This led to the Port of Brunswick handling a record 775,000 automobiles and heavy machinery units in calendar year 2023. Lynch expects the 2024 fiscal year that ends June 30 to be even stronger, exceeding 800,000 auto and machinery units.

The impact of the Baltimore shutdown is expected to subside by then, as the damaged ship Dali was refloated and escorted back to port by tugboats on Monday. A controlled demolition earlier this month broke down the largest remaining span of the collapsed bridge. Baltimore's port director says the shipping channel will be cleared to its full 700-foot width sometime in June.

"The Baltimore thing will now subside," Lynch said of Georgia's auto import influx from the shutdown to the north. "I would think in the next couple of weeks, we're done." With the Port of Brunswick handling a significant volume of automobile shipments, it is clear that the impact of the Baltimore bridge collapse has been substantial and short-lived.

In conclusion, the Georgia Ports Authority's record-breaking automobile shipments are a testament to the port's ability to adapt and absorb changes in the market. As the shipping channel at Baltimore is expected to return to normal operations soon, it will be interesting to see how this affects the flow of automobiles into the region.

The 19-acre property that was once home to the Atlanta Civic Center has been vacant for over a decade, but now it's set to undergo a major redevelopment. The Atlanta City Council has approved an ambitious plan that includes an affordable senior residential building, five multifamily residential high-rises, a 10-story hotel, a 12-story office building, commercial developments, a public school, and a performing arts center.

Wendy Jamerson, a member of the Fourth Ward West Neighborhood Association, is excited about the redevelopment. Her community has been working to balance density with preserving the landscape and topography of the area. "It's been difficult," she said. "We've had a significant in-town homeless population. This area doesn't have high-rises, so we wanted to make sure there was the right balance."

The plan found unanimous support from the Atlanta City Council, with Councilmember Amir Farokhi calling it a new chapter for the neighborhood. The first phase of the redevelopment is scheduled to begin at the end of this year, and a portion of the project will be ready to show off during the World Cup in 2026.

The developer, Atlanta Housing, has a mandate to provide affordable housing, and hundreds or more affordable housing units are expected to be included in the development. Farokhi emphasized that the redevelopment is not just about buildings, but also about lifting up the community. "This development is going to have a huge impact on this neighborhood," he said.

The only concern expressed by residents is the potential for increased traffic. Many are asking the developer and the Atlanta Housing Authority to consider adding bicycle lanes and alternative transportation options to mitigate this issue.

Overall, the redevelopment plan has been met with enthusiasm from the community, and it's expected that it will bring new life to the area. The project is a testament to the city's commitment to revitalizing underutilized spaces and providing affordable housing options for its residents.

The redevelopment of the former Atlanta Civic Center site is not just about building new structures; it's also about honoring the history of the area while bringing in a new chapter. As Jamerson said, "We wanted to make sure there was the right balance." The project will bring together different types of housing, commercial developments, and community facilities, making it a truly mixed-use development.

One of the most exciting aspects of the redevelopment is the performing arts center, which will provide a space for local artists to showcase their work. This will not only be a great asset for the community but also help to boost the local economy.

The affordable senior residential building and the multifamily residential high-rises are expected to be popular among residents looking for housing options in the area. The office building and hotel will provide job opportunities and increase foot traffic in the area, making it more vibrant and lively.

As the redevelopment moves forward, the community is excited to see the transformation take shape. With the World Cup just around the corner, the timing of the project's first phase couldn't be better. It's expected that the new development will bring a lot of attention to the area, which could ultimately benefit local businesses and residents.

In conclusion, the redevelopment plan for the former Atlanta Civic Center site is an exciting opportunity for the community to come together and create something new and vibrant. articles.title: Military Letters Bring Joy to Unmet Heroes: A Lasting Legacy
articles.content:
As I stepped into the Cottonwood Estates Retirement Living facility in Alpharetta, Georgia, I was met with a sense of nostalgia and purpose. Senior Helpers had organized an initiative to encourage residents to write letters to military personnel they would never meet. The goal was simple yet profound: to bring joy and comfort to those serving our country.

Chris Werthman, an 84-year-old Army Veteran, sat in his chair, pen in hand, reflecting on the impact these letters can have. "When you're in the military, it's so great to get letters," he said with a warm smile. "And then getting 20 of them at one time? It's even better!" Werthman's eyes lit up as he recalled receiving multiple letters from strangers during his service.

The idea of writing letters may seem simple, but its significance cannot be overstated. For many military personnel, receiving letters from home can be a much-needed morale booster in the face of uncertainty and danger. The handwritten words bring a sense of connection to loved ones and a reminder that they are not forgotten.

As I spoke with Werthman, it became clear that this initiative was more than just a feel-good activity – it was an opportunity for seniors to share their experiences and connect with others who have served. For those writing the letters, it's a chance to pay tribute to the sacrifices made by military personnel and to show appreciation for their service.

The rules of this initiative were clear: write from your heart and leave politics at the door. The focus is on expressing gratitude and support, rather than promoting any particular agenda. This approach allows the writers to tap into their own personal experiences and emotions, creating letters that are authentic and heartfelt.

As I left Cottonwood Estates, I couldn't help but think about the ripple effect of these letters. Imagine receiving 20 handwritten notes from strangers, each one a testament to the kindness and appreciation of those back home. The impact would be immeasurable, a reminder that even in times of turmoil, there is always hope and gratitude to be found.

As we continue to navigate the complexities of war and conflict, it's essential to remember the human side of military service. These letters are more than just a gesture – they're a bridge between strangers and a symbol of our collective appreciation for those who serve. By writing from our hearts and leaving politics behind, we can create a lasting legacy that transcends borders and ideologies.

In an era where division and discord often dominate the headlines, it's heartwarming to see individuals come together in support of our military personnel. The letters written at Cottonwood Estates Retirement Living are a powerful reminder that even small acts of kindness can have a profound impact on those serving our country.

As I concluded my visit, I couldn't help but feel a sense of pride and gratitude for the seniors who took the time to write these letters. Their stories are a testament to the power of human connection and the enduring legacy of military service.

articles.title: Black Women's Voices Key to Bridging Cancer Inequity Gap
articles.content:
The American Cancer Society has launched the largest focused study on Black women, aimed at understanding why they are disproportionately affected by aggressive types of cancer. The three-decade long research initiative, titled "Voices of Black Women," seeks to gather insights from 100,000 Black women on their lifestyle habits, medical conditions, and experiences with racism and discrimination.

Dr. Lauren McCullough, a leading researcher on the project, emphasized the significance of this study in bridging the cancer inequity gap affecting Black women. As one of the study's key investigators, Dr. McCullough is well-positioned to provide valuable insights into the factors contributing to this disparity.

The American Cancer Society reported that Black women have the highest death rate of any racial or ethnic group for most cancers in the United States. This staggering statistic underscores the urgent need for a comprehensive investigation into the root causes of these inequities.

Dr. McCullough highlighted the importance of this study, stating, "We see you, we honor you, and we hope to partner with you to improve health." She added that the research aims to better understand Black women's lived experiences, how they engage with the medical care system, and how comorbid conditions may impact their treatment and care.

The Voices of Black Women study is a critical step forward in addressing the persistent disparities in cancer outcomes among Black women. By involving 100,000 participants from 20 states and Washington D.C., this initiative will provide unprecedented insights into the complex factors contributing to these inequities.

As Dr. McCullough herself acknowledged, "Black women's voices have been muzzled for a very long time, but we want to show the power in their voices." The American Cancer Society is now seeking eligible participants – Black women between 25 and 55 years of age who have never had cancer – to enroll in this groundbreaking study.

articles.title: Airline Industry Takes Flight with Hydrogen-Powered Future
articles.content:
As the world continues to grapple with the consequences of climate change, a new study at Hartsfield-Jackson Atlanta International Airport has shed light on the potential for hydrogen fueling to reduce carbon emissions in the airline industry. The airport is partnering with Delta Air Lines, Airbus, and Plug Power to investigate the feasibility of future hydrogen fueling, a move that could significantly impact the environment.

According to officials, the study aims to measure infrastructure, safety requirements, and other variables until the end of 2026. Michael Smith, senior deputy general manager at Hartsfield-Jackson, expressed enthusiasm for the project, stating, "Hartsfield-Jackson has long been a leader in the commercial aviation industry, and it only makes sense that we help lead this effort." He added, "If hydrogen proves to be a viable alternative, ATL will investigate options to update infrastructure in order to implement the new technology. We are thrilled to participate in this study and look forward to the results."

Hydrogen fuel cells, which combine oxygen and hydrogen atoms to create electricity, have the potential to significantly reduce carbon emissions. Unlike traditional fossil fuels, hydrogen fuel cells produce water as their main byproduct, alongside a small amount of heat. This eco-friendly technology has already been used to power electrical systems in spacecraft, experimental buses, trains, and planes.

The study at Hartsfield-Jackson is part of Airbus' Hydrogen Hub at Airports program, which aims to launch the world's first hydrogen-powered commercial plane by 2035. The company has partnered with airports worldwide to explore the potential for hydrogen fueling. In 2022, Hartsfield-Jackson joined the Airbus ZEROe program, which seeks to determine the logistics of hydrogen planes.

Karine Guénan, vice president of Airbus' ZEROe Ecosystem, emphasized the significance of hydrogen in reducing the environmental impact of aviation, stating, "The U.S. has easy and massive access to additional renewable energies to produce green hydrogen, and airports are looking for a diverse and balanced energy mix to be more resilient and help reduce the impact of aviation on the environment. Hydrogen is a key enabler for this."

As the world continues to shift towards a more sustainable future, the study at Hartsfield-Jackson Atlanta International Airport marks an important step forward in the development of hydrogen-powered commercial flights. With the potential to significantly reduce carbon emissions, it's clear that the airline industry is taking flight with hydrogen fueling.

articles.title: Tragedy Strikes Deerfield-Windsor Community: Recent Graduate Dies in Car Crash
articles.content:
As authorities continue to investigate the circumstances surrounding a fatal car crash that occurred on Monday, May 20, the Deerfield-Windsor community is reeling from the loss of one of its own. According to Georgia State Patrol (GSP), troopers responded to a single-vehicle accident on Bobby Locke Road in Terrell County around 2:00 a.m., where they found a white Ford F-150 had veered off the highway and crashed into a culvert, becoming airborne before hitting a tree with its roof. The driver, David Mullins, was pronounced dead at the scene, while his passenger, Vansh Patel, was ejected from the vehicle and airlifted to Grady Memorial Hospital.

GSP officials have released few details about the crash, but it is believed that the vehicle exited the highway as it navigated a curve, striking a culvert and becoming airborne before hitting the tree. The cause of the accident remains under investigation.

Mullins' death has sent shockwaves through the Deerfield-Windsor community, where he was a recent graduate and student-athlete. Head Football Coach Brian McCrae paid tribute to Mullins on social media, calling for the school's students and staff to "rally around our loved ones" and live life as Mullins would have wanted them to.

In addition to his athletic achievements, Mullins had also been awarded a $2,000 scholarship from the Albany Rotary Club, which he planned to use to attend the University of Georgia. His plans were cut short by the tragic accident, leaving friends, family, and the wider community to mourn his loss.

As news of the tragedy spreads, Deerfield-Windsor Head of School Allen Lowe has announced that the school will be providing support to students and families affected by Mullins' passing. No further details have been released about the nature of this support or how it will be implemented.

In the wake of this devastating loss, communities across South Georgia are coming together to pay their respects to David Mullins and his loved ones. As WALB continues to follow this story, we will bring you updates as more information becomes available.

For now, the Deerfield-Windsor community is left to grieve and reflect on the life of a young man who had so much to look forward to.

articles.title: Football Star's Reckless Driving Arrest Highlights Team's Off-Field Concerns
articles.content:
The arrest of a University of Georgia wide receiver on charges of reckless driving and going the wrong way on a one-way road has raised concerns about the team's off-field behavior, particularly in light of previous incidents involving UGA football players.

According to Athens-Clarke County Jail records, Sacovie White, a freshman from Cartersville, was booked around 4 a.m. on Saturday after being arrested for reckless driving and going the wrong way on a one-way road. White posted a $26 bond and was released, records show.

This latest incident is not an isolated occurrence. In March, running back Trevor Etienne was arrested and charged with DUI, reckless driving, failure to maintain his lane, and affixing materials that reduce the visibility of windows or windshield, according to jail records. He was released on a $1,883 bond.

The most notable crash related to the team occurred in January 2023, which killed offensive lineman Devin Willock and UGA staffer Chandler LeCroy just hours after UGA's national football championship parade. According to an ongoing lawsuit filed by a former UGA recruiting analyst who was riding in the backseat, LeCroy was street racing against former UGA star defensive lineman Jalen Carter when the accident happened.

The suit also partially blames the University of Georgia's athletics association for renting out the car that was involved in the crash. The plaintiff claims that the organization wrongfully rented out the vehicle, which contributed to the accident.

These incidents have raised concerns about the team's culture and whether it is fostering a sense of accountability among its players. While it is not uncommon for college athletes to get into trouble off the field, these types of incidents can have serious consequences and damage the reputation of the team and the university as a whole.

In response to these incidents, UGA has implemented measures to improve player behavior and accountability. These measures include increased coaching staff oversight, improved mentorship programs, and enhanced community outreach initiatives.

Despite these efforts, it remains to be seen whether they will be effective in changing the culture of the team and reducing the number of off-field incidents. As the university continues to grapple with these issues, it is clear that a comprehensive approach is needed to address the root causes of these problems and ensure that the team's reputation is not tarnished by negative behavior.

articles.title: Georgia Sheriff Primary Election Sees Drama as Candidate Removed from Ballot
articles.content:
The Georgia primary elections have taken an unexpected turn with the removal of Walter Woolfork from the Henry County Sheriff's race just hours before polls opened. The Elections Board disqualified Woolfork due to issues surrounding his fingerprint submission, which failed to meet constitutional and statutory qualifications for the office.

Woolfork claimed he had submitted his fingerprints at the County Sheriff's Office, rather than the Probate Court as mandated by O.C.G.A 15-16-1(c)(1)(G). He expressed frustration that the Board did not alert him of this mistake until four days before the election, effectively disqualifying him from the race.

The removal of Woolfork leaves three candidates vying for the Democratic nomination: Willie Brown, Cornell "CJ" Madison, and incumbent Reginald Scandrett. Madison, one of the remaining candidates, reported that roughly 1,500 campaign signs had been stolen over the weekend, costing around $20,000 in raised funds.

Madison claimed the thefts occurred outside gas stations, street corners, and front yards of homes, with dashcam footage obtained by Atlanta News First showing a white truck pulling up to a home, stealing a campaign banner, and driving off. Residents of the home verified the incident, and the Henry County Police Department is investigating.

Madison emphasized his commitment to addressing issues at the Henry County Jail, where six people have died in custody since 2023, according to the Sheriff's Office. He believes improving conditions and implementing county funds more effectively would be top priorities if elected.

Incumbent Reginald Scandrett declined to comment on the stolen signs, instead focusing on Woolfork's removal from the ballot. "The removal of a candidate Woolfork from the ballot, while unfortunate, is within the realm of the Board of Elections and Voter Registration," he stated.

Willie Brown, another remaining candidate, did not respond to Atlanta News First's requests for comment. As voters head to the polls, this unexpected twist has raised questions about the integrity of the election process and the qualifications of candidates seeking public office.

The challenge aims to showcase applicants' breadth and depth of talent, commitment, and interest in esports and gaming as a career. Austen Roberts, head of production and executive producer at Skillshot Media, emphasized that the BroadcastHER Academy has the potential to be life-changing for the selected Fellows.

The program will provide Fellows with valuable opportunities and experiences that can open doors to employment. The BroadcastHER Academy is an initiative that has gained recognition for its efforts in advancing women's representation in esports and gaming.

As the industry continues to evolve, it is essential to have programs like the BroadcastHER Academy, which aim to create a more inclusive environment. By providing training opportunities and experiential learning experiences, the program can help bridge the gap between the number of women who game and those who work in content creation and esports roles.

The BroadcastHER Academy has already seen remarkable results from its previous Fellows, with some experiencing incredible career growth after completing the program. The initiative's success is a testament to its effectiveness in empowering women in the esports and gaming industry.

In conclusion, the BroadcastHER Academy fellowship program is an essential step towards creating a more inclusive and diverse esports industry. articles.title: Georgia Primary Election Approaches as Early Voting Closes
articles.content:
As Georgia's primary election approaches, candidates are gearing up for the final push to win their party's nomination and secure a spot on the November general election ballot. With early voting coming to a close, officials are urging voters to make sure their absentee ballots have been accepted before heading to the polls on Tuesday.

According to the Georgia Secretary of State's Office, over 513,000 people had already cast their ballots as of Friday, with around 65,000 opting for absentee voting. However, concerns about delay issues at U.S. Postal Service locations have led officials to recommend checking the Secretary of State's ballot tracker page to ensure absentee ballots have been received.

"We were in really bad shape with the USPS, but our office has put the hammer down on them and they've developed an action plan," said Gabriel Sterling, chief operating officer of the Georgia Secretary of State's Office. "They've redeployed about 150 employees, bringing them to the state and out of the state."

As voters prepare for Election Day, officials are emphasizing the importance of bringing identification to polling places and ensuring that voters visit their assigned precincts.

In Fulton County, several high-profile races are garnering attention, including the contests between Sheriff Patrick Labat and his challengers, as well as the showdown between Fulton County Superior Court Judge Scott McAfee and radio host Robert Patillo. Incumbent Fani Willis is facing off against attorney Christian Wise Smith in a heated race for Fulton County district attorney.

Meanwhile, voters across the state will also be deciding on a seat on the Georgia Supreme Court, with incumbent Justice Andrew Pinson facing challenger John Barrow. The race has gained attention due to Barrow's pledge to protect abortion rights if the state's controversial six-week abortion ban comes before the court.

"We need to keep a justice system that's fair and impartial," said Pinson, an appointee of Gov. Brian Kemp. "Or we can have a system where partisan politicians are in black robes."

As voters make their way to the polls on Tuesday, officials are urging them to take advantage of early voting or absentee ballots if they cannot cast their ballots in person.

articles.title: Car Wash Chaos: Three-Car Pileup Leaves Drivers Shaken
articles.content:
The incident occurred at the Super Duck Car Wash in Snellville, Georgia, where three cars collided due to a malfunctioning car wash system. The first car, driven by Maria Ruiz, was taken in for a routine clean when the big brush in the middle of the tunnel came down and hit the luggage rack on top of her cousin's Chevy Tahoe. This caused the vehicle to shift to the right, prompting Ruiz to express concern about the car wash's emergency shutoff system.

Behind Ruiz was BeinSon Bracey, who regularly takes his 2010 Porsche Panamera into the car wash. As he approached the same section of the tunnel, he noticed the first car had stopped moving and began beeping his horn to alert others behind him. Unfortunately, his warning came too late, as a third vehicle crashed into the back of his Porsche, causing it to be slowly sandwiched between the two cars.

According to eyewitness accounts, including those from Ruiz and Bracey, the car wash immediately shut off after the incident, and both drivers were escorted out of the tunnel. Bracey quickly dialed 911 and waited for a Gwinnett County Police officer to arrive on scene. The officer reviewed footage from the car wash, stating that "within this footage, I observed vehicle one fail to go into neutral and observed the vehicle engage its brakes while moving through the car wash."

Ruiz claims that the car wash had a major malfunction when it came to an emergency shutoff. She believes that if a vehicle jumps off track, the car wash should take steps to prevent similar incidents from occurring in the future. Bracey is preparing for an expensive repair bill after taking his damaged Porsche to a shop on Monday.

The insurance company, Progressive, has attributed the accident to Bracey's actions rather than the car wash malfunction. The general manager of Super Duck Car Wash has not responded to Bracey's requests for communication. As a result, Bracey is urging drivers to stay alert while going through car washes, as unexpected incidents can occur when another vehicle suddenly goes off track.

The incident serves as a reminder of the importance of safety and preparedness during everyday activities like taking a car in for a routine clean. In this case, the malfunctioning car wash system contributed to a chaotic and potentially dangerous situation that could have been avoided with proper functioning of the emergency shutoff.

As the investigation continues, questions remain about the cause of the malfunction and what steps will be taken to prevent similar incidents from happening in the future. For now, drivers are advised to exercise caution when using car washes and to be aware of their surroundings at all times.

articles.title: "President Biden Delivers Commencement Address at Morehouse College, Confronting Concerns of Students and Faculty on Israel-Hamas War"

ATLANTA, GA - In a highly anticipated and closely watched event, President Joe Biden delivered the commencement address at Morehouse College on Sunday. The historic Black college, known for its rich legacy of producing influential leaders such as Martin Luther King Jr., welcomed Biden to its campus despite weeks of protests and concerns from students, faculty, and alumni over his administration's approach to the Israel-Hamas war.

As the packed crowd gathered in the quad, Associate Provost Mel Foster warned that while peaceful protests would be tolerated, any disruptions would halt the ceremony. The atmosphere was tense as protesters approached the college entrance, with some chanting "Move cops, get out the way." Atlanta police were on hand to maintain order.

Biden began his speech by lauding the graduates and their families. He then turned his attention to the concerns of students and faculty over his administration's stance on the Israel-Hamas war, acknowledging that there is pain and a lot of opinions on the issue.

The president reiterated his calls for an immediate cease-fire between Israel and Hamas, emphasizing that a two-state solution is the only way forward. He also spoke about political extremism in America, decrying its ongoing threats to democracy.

In addressing the concerns of Morehouse students and faculty, Biden acknowledged their right to have opinions and respect their perspectives. He emphasized his understanding of the pain and struggles faced by many, particularly within the Black community.

The president's remarks were met with a mix of applause and criticism from the audience. Many graduates and guests appeared moved by his words, while others remained skeptical or even angry over what they perceived as insufficient acknowledgment of their concerns.

As he departed Atlanta for Detroit, where he planned to address an NAACP dinner, Biden's visit to Morehouse College marked the first time he had returned to the Peach State since a March campaign rally. His speech at Morehouse was part of a burst of outreach to Black constituents by the president, who has watched his support among these voters soften since their strong backing helped put him in the Oval Office in 2020.

Georgia and Michigan are among a handful of states that will help decide November's expected rematch between Biden and Republican former President Donald Trump. Biden narrowly won Georgia and Michigan in 2020 and needs to repeat those victories - with a boost from strong Black voter turnout in Atlanta and Detroit.

articles.title: Election of Conservative Activist Amy Kremer to Republican National Committee Sparks Division and Calls for Unity
articles.content:
The recent election of conservative activist Amy Kremer to the Republican National Committee has sparked division within the party, with some calling for unity and others advocating for a more confrontational approach. Kremer, who helped organize the January 6, 2021, pro-Trump rally that led to a mob storming the U.S. Capitol, was chosen by delegates at the convention in Columbus.

Kremer's election came after a split decision by delegates, with some arguing that incumbent Committeeman Jason Thompson had not done enough to support Donald Trump. Kremer and other challengers pointed out the continued desire of party activists for confrontation with internal and external enemies, even as many in leadership tried to preach unity and ease divisions.

"We need somebody willing to stand up and fight," Kremer told delegates. "If you want the grassroots to have a voice, then you need to vote for change." Kremer's group secured the permit for the "Save America" rally where Trump told the crowd to "fight like hell," and she was among the most active fundraisers in the "Stop the Steal" movement.

Despite attacks on Kremer, including unpaid Federal Election Commission fines by her affiliated group, delegates reelected Thompson. However, Thompson fell short of a majority in an initial three-candidate race but won in a runoff.

Thompson told delegates, "Together we will fight the forces that seek to destroy America. Together we will win the state of Georgia for President Trump." Most speakers called on Republicans to put their internal divisions behind them, including U.S. Rep. Marjorie Taylor Greene, who earned rebukes from other Republicans during her failed attempt to oust U.S. House Speaker Mike Johnson.

Greene told attendees at a party breakfast Saturday that "there's nothing wrong with a little bit of arguing in the Republican Party" but those divisions should stop now. She noted that if Republicans are too fractured, they cannot work together to hit that home run in November.

The fracture deepened when some party leaders supported former U.S. Sen. David Perdue's unsuccessful, Trump-backed challenge to Gov. Brian Kemp in 2022. However, there were signs of unity, with two Kemp allies speaking at the convention and a larger number of state lawmakers attending than last year.

Party Chairman Josh McKoon said that was part of his attempt to fuse the party back together. "That's another thing we've been working on, is our relationship with elected officials and kind of bringing everybody back to the table," McKoon said.

Republicans repeatedly said they believe inflation and immigration are the issues that will allow them to win over people who didn't vote in 2020 or who voted for Biden. Georgia Labor Commissioner Bruce Thompson brandished his wallet during a Friday speech to tell delegates how to reach undecided voters.

"Don't pound them over abortion, don't pound over things that maybe aren't relevant," Thompson said. "Pound them over what really matters, which is right here. This is relevant to every single American. It's their pocketbook."

articles.title: Benjamin Franklin Parkway Celebrates Centennial of Urban Revitalization
articles.content:
As I walk along the Benjamin Franklin Parkway, I am struck by the beauty and elegance of this iconic Philadelphia landmark. But few may know that the Parkway's design was inspired by a stretch of Parisian boulevard, the Champs-Élysées. This cultural treasure is a testament to the power of urban revitalization, which transformed an industrial city into a hub of commerce and culture.

The City Beautiful movement of the 1890s aimed to create a new American aesthetic, moving away from an industrial landscape towards an urban paradise. The Parkway's creation was a direct result of this movement, with architects Jacques Gréber and Paul Cret collaborating on designs that would eventually shape the parkway. Their vision was not just to build a road, but to create a scenic corridor lined with small parks, each with its own unique character.

The demolition process took 10 years, from 1907 to 1917, during which time the area looked barren and empty. However, this was not the desired outcome. To address this, pergolas were installed along the parkway to create a more visually appealing space. It wasn't until 1926 that the plans were finally completed, and the Parkway became the centerpiece of the City Beautiful movement.

The Parkway's design is simple yet effective, featuring a straight line that connects City Hall Tower to Fairmount Park. This straightforward approach has resulted in a beautiful and easily navigable space that has become synonymous with Philadelphia. Without this transformation, the city might have remained an industrial hub with row house neighborhoods and few cultural attractions.

Today, the Benjamin Franklin Parkway is a testament to the power of urban revitalization, showcasing what can be achieved through careful planning and design. As I continue my stroll along the parkway, I am reminded of the importance of preserving our cultural heritage for future generations.

articles.title: Daily Marijuana Use Outnumbers Daily Drinking in US, Study Finds
articles.content:
A recent analysis of national survey data has revealed that millions of people in the United States report using marijuana daily or nearly every day, surpassing those who say they are daily or near-daily drinkers of alcohol for the first time. According to the study's author, Jonathan Caulkins, a cannabis policy researcher at Carnegie Mellon University, around 40% of current cannabis users engage in daily or near-daily use, a pattern more commonly associated with tobacco use than typical alcohol consumption.

The research, published in the journal Addiction, is based on data from the National Survey on Drug Use and Health. The survey is a highly regarded source of self-reported estimates of tobacco, alcohol, and drug use in the United States. In 2022, an estimated 17.7 million people reported using marijuana daily or near-daily compared to 14.7 million daily or near-daily drinkers.

From 1992 to 2022, the per capita rate of reporting daily or near-daily marijuana use increased 15-fold. Caulkins acknowledged that people may be more willing to report marijuana use as public acceptance grows, which could boost the increase. Most states now allow medical or recreational marijuana, though it remains illegal at the federal level.

In November, Florida voters will decide on a constitutional amendment allowing recreational cannabis, and the federal government is moving to reclassify marijuana as a less dangerous drug. The study's findings suggest that more people are at risk for developing problematic cannabis use or addiction due to the increasing number of daily users.

High-frequency users are more likely to become addicted to marijuana, said Dr. David A. Gorelick, a psychiatry professor at the University of Maryland School of Medicine, who was not involved in the study. "High frequency use also increases the risk of developing cannabis- associated psychosis," a severe condition where a person loses touch with reality.

The study's author, Caulkins, emphasized that the increasing prevalence of daily marijuana use is a concern. "A good 40% of current cannabis users are using it daily or near-daily, a pattern that is more associated with tobacco use than typical alcohol use," he said.

The findings have significant implications for public health and policy. As the popularity of marijuana continues to grow, so too does the risk of addiction and other negative consequences. The study's results highlight the need for increased education and awareness about the potential risks and benefits of marijuana use.

In conclusion, the recent analysis of national survey data has revealed a significant shift in marijuana use patterns in the United States. As daily marijuana use continues to increase, it is essential that we prioritize public health and policy initiatives to mitigate the negative consequences associated with high-frequency marijuana use.

articles.title: Prison Labor Reform Urged by Sen. Cory Booker
articles.content:
Sen. Cory Booker emphasized the need for prison labor reform during a Senate judiciary subcommittee hearing on Tuesday. The New Jersey Democrat highlighted the problematic nature of forcing prisoners to work without fair compensation or protection from harm.

Booker noted that the United States has one of the highest incarceration rates in the world, with nearly 2 million people behind bars. He stressed that those who refuse to work can be punished, including being thrown into solitary confinement. Additionally, those injured or killed while working often do not have access to basic rights and protections guaranteed to other American workers.

The hearing aimed at exploring ways to rethink prison labor, from making jobs voluntary and boosting wages to protecting workers against injuries and abuse. Booker emphasized that prisons should reflect the values of society, serving as a place for rehabilitation rather than just punishment.

Some companies, such as McDonald's, KFC, Walmart, Cargill, and Tyson Foods, have benefited from the multibillion-dollar industry. However, this has led to concerns about the treatment and compensation of incarcerated workers.

Republican Sen. Tom Cotton of Arkansas pushed back against the idea of reforming prison labor, stating that prisoners are dangerous individuals housed in dangerous facilities where "idle hands are the devil's workshop." He believed that prison labor is a way for inmates to give something back to society, even if it means performing menial tasks like scrubbing toilets or picking up garbage.

The practice of putting prisoners to work dates back to the early 1800s, but the current system has its roots in the post-Civil War era. The 13th Amendment contained a loophole that allowed for forced labor of former slaves, which was exploited by industrial giants during the convict leasing era.

Andrea Armstrong, a law professor at Loyola University New Orleans, highlighted the dangers and lack of accountability surrounding prison labor. She noted that incarcerated workers are often given dangerous assignments with little training, leading to preventable deaths and lifelong injuries. Refusing to work in such conditions can even lead to new criminal charges and sentences.

The hearing aimed to spark a national conversation about the need for reform and transparency in prison labor practices. Booker's emphasis on rehabilitation over punishment reflects the values of many Americans who believe that prisoners should have the opportunity to redeem themselves while behind bars.

articles.title: Trenton Takes Next Step in Lead Cleanup Efforts: Testing for Kids Exposed to Toxic Chemical
articles.content:
The city of Trenton has announced its next move in tackling the ongoing issue of elevated lead levels in soil and waterways, focusing on testing students who may have been exposed to the poisonous chemical. This development comes after the federal government stepped in to identify areas with high levels of lead in January, followed by the city's response to close parts of three parks in April.

City officials have shifted their attention to testing 600 students from Grant Intermediate School, which has been contaminated with lead. The move is aimed at addressing concerns from parents like Melanie Bajek, who worries that the work being done to remove lead might not be enough to ensure her son's health. "I just think if something happens to our kids at any point, they're going to try to say that the exposure happened at home instead of at the school," she said.

The city has also launched a door-to-door testing initiative in Trenton's North Ward section, where employees from the city's health department will be offering free testing for parents. This effort is part of Mayor Reed Gusciora's push to address the issue. "We're testing people's yards, we're testing schools, we're testing parks," he said. "But also, we have these old homes that have lead-based paints on the walls. Kids get serious, they put the chips of the paint in their mouths."

The city closed off grass areas at Sony Vereen Playground, Breunig Avenue Park, and Grant Avenue Playground in April after the EPA found high levels of lead in the soil at these locations. Public Health Officer Yvette Graffie-Cooper emphasized the importance of acting quickly to prevent irreversible lead poisoning. "Lead poisoning is irreversible. So we are trying to do all that we can before we get to that point," she said.

City officials attribute Trenton's history with pottery factories using lead paint as a key factor in the high levels of lead found throughout the city. While they acknowledge that they cannot change the past, they aim to create a safer environment for future generations.

As the process of removing lead from Trenton takes years to complete, parents like Bajek are seeking long-term solutions. "My kids are going to a different school next year because I don't like what goes on – it's a quick fix and our kids are the ones suffering at the end of the day because they're the ones being exposed to it," she said.

In contrast, Darlene McKnight Elementary School was tested by the EPA and found to have no high levels of lead. While progress is being made, officials acknowledge that much work remains to be done in making Trenton's environment safer for its residents.

articles.title: Jersey Shore Beachgoers Face New Rules: No Large Tents or Canopies Allowed

The Jersey Shore is gearing up for another busy summer season, but beachgoers can expect some changes to their typical beach activities. In a bid to preserve dwindling beach space, several popular shore destinations in New Jersey have introduced new rules banning large tents, canopies, and similar structures.

According to officials, the main reason behind this decision is severe erosion, which has left many beaches with limited or no sand at all. Lifeguards in North Wildwood are taking extra precautions by setting up their stands early and keeping a close eye on beachgoers who show up with prohibited structures.

The ban on large tents and canopies aims to ensure public safety during medical emergencies and prevent any potential hazards from these structures. In areas where the tide is high, there's often little to no sand available for sitting or relaxation.

North Wildwood Mayor Patrick Rosenello emphasized that the city is doing its best to make as much beach space available as possible to accommodate the increasing number of visitors. Similarly, Brick Township officials have also implemented similar restrictions for the summer season, citing a long-awaited replenishment project that is still months away.

Island Beach State Park has gone one step further by introducing a ban on tents and canopies in swimming areas effective Memorial Day weekend. articles.title: Philadelphia Manhunt Underway for Fourth Suspect in Off-Duty Officer Attack
articles.content:
The search continues for Arthur Jones, 38, the fourth and final suspect involved in the brutal attack on off-duty Philadelphia Police Officer Eric Rodriguez earlier this month. Authorities are offering a $5,000 reward for information leading to his arrest.

According to investigators, Jones is described as a 5-foot-6 man weighing around 160 pounds with black hair, brown eyes, and a tattoo of dice on his left forearm. His last known address was on the 600 block of W. Harold Street. If anyone has any information regarding his whereabouts, they are encouraged to contact the U.S. Marshals Philadelphia Tipline at 1-866-865-TIPS (8477) or Philadelphia Police.

The investigation into the May 12 attack on Officer Rodriguez began after he was brutally assaulted by multiple individuals while sitting in his car. The incident occurred around 7 a.m. along the 2100 block of Oxford Avenue, where Officer Rodriguez became stuck in traffic behind another vehicle. After waiting through several red lights, he honked his horn, which prompted one of the suspects, Cian Dennis, also known as "Duke," to approach him and punch him in the face.

Officer Rodriguez then got out of his vehicle and identified himself as a police officer, at which point Dennis allegedly pulled out a gun and held it down by his side. The two struggled over the weapon, while another suspect, Yusef Coleman, approached Officer Rodriguez from behind and placed him in a headlock. Coleman was also armed, and the two men began to struggle over the gun.

Officer Rodriguez managed to push the gun away, causing the magazine to fall out. He then fired the remaining round, but no one was struck by the gunfire. Dennis then pointed his gun at Officer Rodriguez and demanded he let go of the weapon. Meanwhile, a nearby after-hours bar had just closed, and a crowd of about a dozen people arrived on the scene.

The responding on-duty officer's arrival caused the crowd to disperse, and Coleman fled the scene in a black BMW, striking Officer Rodriguez's leg. Officer Rodriguez was taken to the hospital and treated for a concussion, multiple injuries to his face, and bruising.

Detectives reviewed Officer Rodriguez's body camera footage as well as surveillance video from the area, which led them to identify Coleman. Police responded to an area where he normally frequented, and later that afternoon, they found him and the black BMW on G and Hilton streets. Coleman was taken into custody and charged with criminal conspiracy, aggravated assault, assault of a law enforcement officer, robbery, theft by unlawful taking, weapon violations, and related offenses.

On Tuesday, May 14, Dennis surrendered to police and was charged with similar offenses. A third suspect, Khamil Brown, was arrested on Wednesday, May 15, after surveillance photos were released. She is also charged with criminal conspiracy, aggravated assault, robbery, theft by unlawful taking, violation of the uniform firearms act, and other related offenses.

Police have recovered Officer Rodriguez's stolen weapon. The officer, a nine-year veteran of the Philadelphia Police Department, is currently assigned to the 22nd District. After he fully recovers from his injuries, he will be placed on administrative leave pending the outcome of the investigation from Internal Affairs.

articles.title: Pennsylvania State Faces Lawsuit Over Wrongful Execution of Teenager in 1931
articles.content:
The family of Alexander McClay Williams, who was executed by the state of Pennsylvania at the age of 16 for a murder he did not commit, has filed a lawsuit seeking damages nearly a century after his death. On Monday, attorneys for Williams' family announced that they were bringing forward a lawsuit against the state and Delaware County over the wrongful execution.

Williams was convicted of murdering Vida Robare, a house matron at the Glen Mills School for Boys, in 1930. However, there were no witnesses to the crime, and Williams was never seen at the scene. Prosecutors relied on coerced confessions from the 16-year-old Williams, ignoring other evidence that pointed to alternative suspects.

The lawsuit notes that Sam Lemon, the great-grandson of Williams' criminal trial attorney, uncovered information showing that evidence against Williams was fabricated. In 2022, after hearing new evidence presented, the Court of Common Pleas for Delaware County vacated the conviction and ordered a new trial. However, the state chose not to retry Williams posthumously, instead expunging his record in 2017.

Williams' relatives have long professed his innocence, and in 2022, Delaware County District Attorney Jack Stollsteimer dismissed charges against the teen, stating that Williams should never have faced charges in the first place. "Sadly, we cannot undo the past," Stollsteimer said then. "However, when, as here, justice can be served by publicly acknowledging such a wrong, we must seize that opportunity."

The lawsuit seeks unspecified punitive damages from the state and Delaware County for their role in Williams' wrongful conviction and execution. The family's attorneys argue that the state's failure to correct the injustice in 1931 has led to decades of suffering and pain for the Williams family.

The case highlights the need for accountability and transparency in our criminal justice system, particularly when it comes to historic cases where justice was not served. The lawsuit is a crucial step towards acknowledging the past wrongs committed by the state and working towards healing and closure for the Williams family.

As the lawsuit moves forward, it remains to be seen whether the state will take responsibility for its role in Williams' wrongful execution and provide compensation to his family. One thing is certain, however: this case serves as a stark reminder of the importance of ensuring that justice is served, even when it comes to cases from decades past.

In addition to the state's liability, the lawsuit also seeks damages from Delaware County for their failure to correct the injustice in 1931. The county has yet to comment on the matter.

The case is a testament to the enduring power of investigative journalism and the importance of holding those in power accountable for their actions. As the lawsuit continues to unfold, it will be interesting to see how the state and Delaware County respond to the family's claims of wrongful conviction and execution.

In the end, this case serves as a powerful reminder that justice delayed is not always justice denied, and that even decades later, it is possible to correct historic wrongs and provide closure for those affected.

articles.title: Hazleton's Latino Residents Seek Change in School Board Elections
articles.content:
The Hazleton Area School District is facing a federal lawsuit over its at-large election system for school board members, which argues that it unfairly shuts out Hispanic residents from gaining representation. The district has a significant lack of responsiveness to the needs of its Hispanic students and parents, with concerns ranging from disparate student discipline to inadequate translators.

Two mothers of children enrolled in the district's schools filed the lawsuit in February, citing violations of the federal Voting Rights Act and the constitutional right to equal protection. They argue that the at-large system dilutes their voting strength and allows non-Hispanic white voters to maintain control over the school board.

The Hazleton Area School District has a student body where nearly two-thirds are Hispanic, but no Hispanic person has ever been elected to its school board. The district's 78,000 residents are comprised of about 55% white, 40% Hispanic, and 5% Black, Asian, or multi-racial.

Latino leaders in the area say that the current system is a challenge for those who are new to the country and may lack stable living arrangements. They also point out that school translators are overworked and understaffed, making it difficult for students without strong English skills to communicate effectively with teachers and administrators.

Vianney Castro, a Democrat who lost the November mayoral election in Hazleton by about 25 percentage points, stated that everything is changing around them, but the district has refused to adapt. Tony Bonomo, president of the Hazleton Area School Board, acknowledged that electing voters by region could be more fair, but the current board members are not likely to initiate such a change.

The school district's lawyer argued in seeking dismissal of the case that the two plaintiffs are not entitled to sue under the Voting Rights Act and that voters are divided more by partisan political affiliation than by race and ethnicity. However, the plaintiffs' lawsuit argues that Hispanic residents have been denied equal protection and voting rights due to the at-large election system.

The Pennsylvania State Education Association reports that 310 of the state's 500 school boards, like Hazleton Area, have boards elected entirely at-large, with 175 elected from regions within the overall district and 15 using a hybrid system. The influx of new residents has long been a topic of conflict in Hazleton, with some areas experiencing growing pains as they work to translate raw numbers into political power.

State Rep. Manny Guzman, a Democrat from Reading and vice chair of the Pennsylvania Legislative Latino Caucus, emphasized the importance of building a bench within these respective areas and turning out voters. The U.S. Justice Department has filed a document supporting the ability of private plaintiffs to bring such challenges under the 1965 Voting Rights Act.

The lawsuit highlights the need for change in the way school board elections are conducted in Hazleton and potentially other districts with significant Hispanic populations. By challenging the at-large system, the plaintiffs aim to promote greater representation and inclusion for Hispanic residents in decision-making processes that affect their children's education.

articles.title: Delaware's Vanity License Plate Program Ruled Unconstitutional
articles.content:
A federal judge has ruled that Delaware's vanity license plate program is unconstitutional, allowing officials to discriminate against certain viewpoints when deciding whether to approve applications. The ruling came in a lawsuit filed by Kari Lynn Overington, a breast cancer survivor whose "FCANCER" license plate was recalled in 2021 due to perceived profanity.

Overington filed the lawsuit after her application for the vanity plate was rejected. She explained that the plate meant "fight cancer," but DMV officials asked her about Facebook posts showing her wearing a T-shirt reading "f--- cancer" and celebrating her "f--- cancer" anniversaries, using an expletive instead of the word "fight." The lawsuit exposed how the Division of Motor Vehicles has handled attempts by drivers to express themselves, including those taking aim at President Joe Biden with "Let's Go Brandon" criticisms.

In ruling for Overington, Judge Gregory Williams rejected the DMV's arguments that the alphanumeric combination of letters and numbers on vanity plates constitutes "government speech" and can be regulated as officials see fit. The judge noted that the Texas case involved the background art and designs on specialty plates, not the alphanumeric text.

The court found that Delaware's regulations permit viewpoint discrimination and are unconstitutionally overbroad and arbitrarily enforced. Unlike in Delaware, Hawaii's rules are more defined and objective, simply banning "vulgar" words while including details about which dictionary should be consulted.

DMV records disclosed in the lawsuit illustrate the arbitrary approach officials have taken in denying vanity plates, using terms such as "negative," "questionable," "mean," "evil," "inappropriate," "disgusting," and "could be offensive." In making their decisions, officials frequently relied on the "Urban Dictionary," a crowd-sourced website that invites people to submit and define slang words and phrases.

A spokesman for the Delaware Department of Transportation said the agency will review the decision before commenting on it and the future of the vanity plate program. A DOT attorney said at a March court hearing that Transportation Secretary Nicole Majeski had talked about getting rid of all vanity plates.

The ruling is significant, as courts in California, Maryland, Rhode Island, and Tennessee have ruled that alphanumeric text on vanity plates is private speech, while Hawaii and Indiana courts have said it is government speech. Delaware's regulations state that no vanity plate can be issued if it is "considered to be obscene" by DMV officials.

The American Civil Liberties Union took up Overington's case, arguing that the program allows for viewpoint discrimination and arbitrary enforcement. The ACLU attorney, Dwayne Bensing, said, "A lot of them, you really got to scratch your head... You kind of saw a race to the bottom... as to who could have the most dirty-minded interpretation."

The ruling is seen as a victory for free speech advocates, as it allows drivers to express themselves on their license plates without fear of retribution or censorship.

articles.title: Casino Revenue Sees Slight Uptick Amid Ongoing Struggle
articles.content:
The New Jersey Division of Gaming Enforcement released figures showing that the state's casinos, horse tracks, and their online partners took in nearly $511 million from gamblers in April. While this represents a 10.4% increase from the same period last year, much of this growth can be attributed to strong internet gambling revenue.

In-person casino winnings continued to lag behind, with six out of nine casinos reporting a decline in revenue from gamblers visiting their facilities. This trend is particularly concerning for Atlantic City's brick-and-mortar casinos, which have historically relied on in-person gaming revenue to drive their business.

Despite this, industry experts are optimistic that the summer months will bring an increase in visitation and subsequently, in-person gaming revenue. Jane Bokunewicz, director of the Lloyd Levenson Institute at Stockton University, notes that improving resort offerings could lead to a shift in the market's overall revenue mix towards non-gaming areas such as food and beverage sales.

In terms of individual casino performance, Borgata saw a 0.5% increase in in-person gaming revenue, while Hard Rock reported a 6% gain. Ocean Casino Resort, on the other hand, experienced a decline of 15.6% due to a temporary shutdown of its casino floor. The remaining casinos reported varying degrees of decline.

When considering internet and sports betting revenue, Borgata took in $107.7 million, while Golden Nugget reported a significant increase of 20.4%. Ocean Casino Resort's online revenue declined by 8.6%, but the property as a whole still managed to generate nearly $35.7 million.

The Meadowlands Racetrack, which offers sports betting services, dominated this market with over $73 million in revenue. Resorts Digital and Caesars Interactive NJ also reported strong performances, taking in $66.4 million and $612,910 respectively.

Internet gambling saw its second-best month ever in April, with nearly $188 million won online, a 18.2% increase from the same period last year. Sports betting brought in over $1 billion in April, with $106 million going towards revenue after expenses.

These figures demonstrate the ongoing struggle for Atlantic City's casinos to adapt to changing market conditions while also highlighting areas of growth and opportunity for improvement. As the industry continues to evolve, it will be crucial for operators to focus on diversifying their revenue streams and offering a comprehensive experience that appeals to visitors.

articles.content:
The latest census data reveals that Philadelphia has maintained its position as the sixth-most populous city in the United States, despite a decline in population throughout the pandemic. According to the US Census Bureau estimates, the City of Brotherly Love lost 3.3% of its population between April 2020 and July 2023, resulting in a net loss of approximately 53,000 residents. This decline brought the city's overall population down to around 1,550,542.

While Philadelphia's population growth has stagnated, other major cities have also experienced losses. In fact, nearly all its peer cities in the Northeast and Midwest saw similar declines, with some experiencing even greater drops. For instance, New York City suffered a 6.2% decrease in population during the peak pandemic years, while Boston and Baltimore's population drops outpaced Philadelphia's decline from 2020 to 2023.

On the other hand, five of the nation's 10 largest cities added population, primarily located in the South and Southwest. This trend is driven by cities like San Antonio, Texas, which saw the largest numerical increase in its population of any city in the country in 2023. The data shows that San Antonio added approximately 22,000 residents last year, bringing its population to around 1,495,295 – or about 55,000 people behind Philadelphia.

The census estimates also highlight San Francisco's significant decline, losing a staggering 7.4% of its population during the same period. Meanwhile, other West Coast cities like San Jose, California, experienced smaller but still notable losses.

Philadelphia's demographic shifts are mirrored in other major US cities. Cities in the Northeast and Midwest are experiencing declining populations due to various factors such as aging demographics, out-migration, and slower economic growth. In contrast, cities in the South and Southwest are seeing population growth driven by a combination of factors including younger demographics, job opportunities, and more affordable living.

These trends underscore the complex and multifaceted nature of urbanization in the United States. As cities continue to evolve and adapt to changing circumstances, understanding these shifts is crucial for policymakers and urban planners to develop effective strategies for managing population growth, addressing social and economic challenges, and fostering sustainable development.

The census data also underscores the importance of regional cooperation and collaboration in addressing common challenges facing cities across the country. By sharing knowledge, best practices, and resources, cities can work together to build more resilient and vibrant communities that meet the needs of their residents.

In conclusion, while Philadelphia's population has stabilized, its story is part of a broader narrative of urbanization and demographic shifts unfolding across the United States. As we look ahead to the future, it is essential to acknowledge these trends and work towards building cities that are more equitable, sustainable, and prosperous for all.

articles.title: Green Day of Understanding Celebrates Jack's Unwavering Spirit
articles.content:
Bridle Path Elementary school students and teachers came together to celebrate a special student, Jack, who has been diagnosed with congenital disorders of glycosylation (CDG). The event aimed to educate students about CDG while honoring Jack's resilience. Teachers wore green attire and shared green snacks with the children, making it an unforgettable experience.

CDG is a rare genetic disorder that affects the addition of sugar building blocks to proteins in cells. When a person has CDG, problems arise in how these sugar molecules are attached to proteins, leading to various health issues. According to the Children's Hospital of Philadelphia (CHOP), this disorder is usually inherited from parents.

The genetic mutation can cause a range of symptoms, including developmental delays, muscle weakness, and vision impairments. As children enter adolescence, additional signs may emerge. Despite these challenges, Jack has adapted remarkably well, and his classmates have grown to appreciate his unique qualities.

On the special CDG day, Jack confidently shared his writing skills with his peers and led a lesson without hesitation. His friends have no qualms about praising him, describing him as "fun and kind," "nice," and someone who "plays with me." Jack's teacher, Laura Grabon, proudly noted that he is reading on grade level, writing his letters and words, and exudes pride in his accomplishments.

The event served as a valuable opportunity for the students to learn about differences at a young age. This understanding will benefit them not only in the present but also in the future. As Jack's teacher, Grabon emphasized that teaching tolerance and acceptance is crucial for building a more compassionate society.

Throughout the celebration, students were encouraged to ask questions and engage with Jack's story. The event aimed to raise awareness about CDG while celebrating Jack's unwavering spirit. By embracing diversity and promoting inclusivity, Bridle Path Elementary school has set a remarkable example for future generations.
