articles.title: Forest Thinning Initiative Expected to Boost Water Supply by 1.8 Billion Gallons over Next 20 Years
articles.content:
Arizona's forests cover roughly 27% of the state, and maintaining their health is crucial for water supply management. In an effort to mitigate the risk of wildfires and promote sustainability, Salt River Project (SRP) has joined forces with Apple to launch a forest initiative. This collaborative project aims to restore nearly 30,000 acres of forests over the next decade.

The focus of this initiative lies in forest thinning, which involves removing or pruning trees to create space for grasses, forbs, and bushes to grow. According to SRP's water and forest sustainability senior manager, Elvy Barton, this approach allows more water to soak into the soils, creating a healthier watershed and ecosystem.

Barton emphasized that wildfires can devastate ecosystems, landscapes, and communities, with far-reaching impacts on Phoenix metro residents who rely on SRP-managed water supplies. Snowfall and rain provide water that travels through the watershed into SRP reservoirs, which are then delivered to 2.5 million homes and businesses in the Valley.

Post-wildfire flooding sends significant amounts of debris, ash, and sediment into streams, lakes, and reservoirs, compromising water quality and storage. The forest thinning project aims to prevent such events by treating overgrowth and promoting a more balanced ecosystem.

SRP has previously collaborated with other major companies on sustainability projects, including Meta and Google. This initiative demonstrates the company's commitment to environmental stewardship and long-term community benefits.

In an interview, Barton noted that wildfires can create crown fires, which are particularly challenging to extinguish. She stressed that forest thinning is a crucial step in maintaining healthy forests and mitigating the risk of devastating wildfires.

The expected outcome of this initiative is a significant boost to Arizona's water supply, with 1.8 billion gallons of water benefiting the state over the next 20 years. This collaborative effort between SRP and Apple underscores the importance of preserving natural habitats for the benefit of both local communities and the broader environment.

After selecting a date, homeowners will receive an email confirmation, and they can then place their bulk trash outside up to a week in advance. This new system allows for more efficient scheduling and minimizes the time trash sits on the curb.

According to Gisella Gonzalez, a Public Works Supervisor with the City of Phoenix, this change will make it easier for residents to manage their bulk trash collection. "With our new program, we're hoping that it'll be a lot more convenient for customers," she said.

One of the benefits of this new system is that it allows homeowners to schedule pickups around ongoing projects or special events, rather than having to wait for quarterly collections. The city will also know exactly which day the pickup will happen and can schedule appointments accordingly.

The quarterly pickup schedule remains in effect until the start date, but residents can begin scheduling bulk trash appointments online in late August 2024. For more information on the program, visit phoenix.gov/publicworks/garbage/bulktrash.

articles.title: TAVR Procedure Gives New Life to 84-Year-Old Darrell Williams
articles.content:
Yuma Regional Medical Center has been performing transcatheter aortic valve replacement (TAVR) procedures for the past decade, and their success stories are numerous. One such story is that of 84-year-old Darrell Williams, who underwent the procedure in March and is now feeling back to normal.

Williams' journey began when he was unable to engage in any physical activity, not even walking. His condition was diagnosed as aortic stenosis, a condition that blocks blood flow in the heart. A cardiology specialist at Yuma Regional Medical Center, Dr. Habteab B. Feseha, performed Williams' procedure, using a minimally invasive approach to replace his original valve with a new prosthetic one.

The FDA first approved TAVR in 2011, and since then, it has revolutionized cardiac care. Before the approval of TAVR, open heart surgery was the only option for patients with narrowed heart valves, but this procedure offered a lower-risk alternative. According to Dr. Feseha, anyone with narrowed heart valves has a significantly lower life expectancy, with only about 20% of them surviving five years.

Williams' experience with TAVR was nothing short of life-changing. He went from being unable to walk to enjoying his favorite activities, such as playing golf and doing the things he loves. "I'm ready to get back and play golf and do the things I like to do," Williams said.

Yuma Regional Medical Center has performed nearly 700 TAVR procedures since they began offering the procedure a decade ago. The hospital's team of specialists, including Dr. Feseha and Abby Cockburn, work together to screen potential patients for the procedure and determine if they are good candidates.

Cockburn explained that the hospital performs about three TAVR procedures weekly, and the results have been overwhelmingly positive. "It's life-changing," she said. "You can have a patient that couldn't do the simplest thing for themselves."

Williams' rehabilitation process has been going smoothly, with him keeping up with his workouts and expressing gratitude for the new lease on life he has been given. "Oh I'm grateful, grateful," Williams said.

Yuma Regional Medical Center's TAVR program is a testament to the power of innovative medical procedures to improve patients' lives. As the hospital continues to celebrate a decade of success with this procedure, it serves as a reminder that there is always hope for those seeking a new chance at life.

articles.title: Cruise Delays and Baggage Woes: Passengers Left Scrambling
articles.content:
As travelers embark on their vacations, the last thing they expect is for their checked luggage to vanish. However, a recent incident involving a family's cruise delay highlights the importance of being prepared for unexpected events. Nicole Cameron's seven-day family cruise turned into a nightmare when her and her 5-year-old son's checked bags failed to arrive at Fort Lauderdale, Florida.

With no choice but to purchase new clothing and essentials, Cameron spent over $1,000 in a desperate attempt to salvage their trip. The ordeal was made even more frustrating by Spirit Airlines' lack of communication, leaving the family without answers for days. It wasn't until they received a call from Alaska Airlines that they finally got some resolution – their missing bags were found on the tarmac.

Travelers have rights when it comes to delayed or lost luggage. According to Katy Nastro, a spokesperson for travel site Going, passengers should contact the airline immediately and start the process of locating their checked bag. The U.S. Department of Transportation regulations require airlines to compensate passengers for reasonable incidental expenses while the baggage is delayed.

articles.title: Arizona Governor Signs Bill to Strengthen Child Sex Predator Prosecution Laws
articles.content:
Governor Katie Hobbs has signed into law a new bill aimed at making it easier to prosecute suspected child sex predators before they physically abuse a victim. The measure, House Bill 2310, establishes a new criminal offense called "child enticement," allowing prosecutors to pursue felony charges against adults who solicit nude photos of children or take steps in furtherance of the sexual abuse of minors.

The bill passed the Arizona House of Representatives last week by a vote of 39-19, overcoming criticism from some groups like the ACLU, which argued that the bill's language was overly broad and could criminalize innocent behavior. However, advocates for the legislation say it is necessary to address the growing problem of child grooming and sexual abuse.

The push to change Arizona's sex crimes law started with an incident involving a 14-year-old freshman on a girls' softball team who said her coach began texting her personal details about his life, including his first sexual experiences. The coach, a man in his 30s, also urged the teen to delete their text messages so they wouldn't be discovered.

The case was investigated by the police department that handled the incident, but ultimately, the Maricopa County Attorney's Office declined to prosecute, citing "burden of proof" issues. However, Anne's family, who brought forward the case, is determined to protect other children and has been working with state Rep. Travis Grantham to introduce a bill defining child grooming as a criminal offense.

The bill, which was amended to replace the term "grooming" with "child enticement," would make it a felony to take any steps to facilitate the sexual abuse of a minor, with harsher penalties if the adult is in a position of trust. The measure also clarifies that it cannot be used to prosecute adults displaying images for legitimate sexual education.

Anne's family stresses that the bill isn't just about teachers or coaches but any adult who interacts with children. They hope that the new law will help prevent similar cases from happening in the future and bring justice to victims of child grooming and sexual abuse.

As Governor Hobbs signed the bill into law, she praised the bravery of Anne and her family for bringing forward their story and advocating for change. "We recognize and appreciate the victim who came forward here," Grantham said during a committee hearing on the bill. "Let's give her a round of applause for her strength and her courage."

articles.title: Tucson University Shooting Verdict Reached: Former Graduate Student Convicted of First-Degree Murder
articles.content:
The trial of Murad Dervish, the former University of Arizona graduate student accused of fatally shooting hydrology professor Thomas Meixner on campus in October 2022, has concluded with a guilty verdict. A Pima County Superior Court jury delivered the decision after deliberating for just under three hours.

Dervish, 48, was convicted of first-degree murder and five other felony counts, including aggravated assault for a bullet that grazed a building manager. The jury reached their verdict after considering evidence presented during the trial, which included testimony from witnesses and experts.

Meixner, 52, was the head of the university's Department of Hydrology and Atmospheric Sciences at the time of his death. Dervish had been a student in the department but was expelled from the program earlier in 2022 due to issues with professors after he received a bad grade.

The prosecution argued that Dervish planned Meixner's killing and purchased the murder weapon, a 9mm handgun, a month before the shooting. The defense, on the other hand, claimed that Dervish was experiencing a psychotic episode at the time of the shooting and did not know right from wrong.

Dramatic moments were seen during the trial, including outbursts by Dervish in the courtroom. Defense attorney Leo Masursky argued that Dervish's behavior was part of his defense strategy to prove insanity. However, other experts have questioned whether this was a tactic or if Dervish genuinely believed it would aid his case.

Dervish is set to be sentenced on June 24 and could face life in prison. The verdict brings closure for Meixner's family and the university community, but it also raises questions about the circumstances surrounding the shooting and the events that led up to it.

As the investigation into Dervish's actions unfolded, authorities revealed that he had been banned from campus and later expelled due to ongoing issues with professors. A flyer with his photograph had been circulated among university staff in February 2022, warning them to call 911 if they saw him on campus.

The trial also uncovered a history of harassment and threats made by Dervish against staff members working in the hydrology department. Witnesses testified that Dervish was wearing a surgical mask and baseball cap as a disguise when he showed up outside Meixner's office and shot him.

Dervish fled the scene but was arrested three hours later after Arizona state troopers stopped his car on a highway more than 120 miles northwest of Tucson. A loaded handgun was found in the vehicle, and the ammunition matched shell casings found at the shooting scene.

The University of Arizona community is still grappling with the loss of Meixner, who was a respected educator and researcher. The verdict brings a sense of closure, but it also raises questions about the university's handling of Dervish's behavior in the months leading up to the shooting. articles.title: Domestic Violence Cases Highlight Need for Holistic Safety Planning
articles.content:
A recent spike in domestic violence cases has highlighted the need for survivors of abuse to develop comprehensive safety plans, rather than relying solely on orders of protection. In the past week alone, three major crimes have been reported, with at least one woman shot to death and two others narrowly escaping harm.

Experts agree that while orders of protection can be a valuable tool in preventing further violence, they are not foolproof. Survivor advocates emphasize that having a safety plan is key, and that this plan should include multiple strategies for staying safe, including but not limited to an order of protection.

According to Emily Perea, Victim Advocate for the City Of Phoenix Family Advocacy Center, "You never know when something like this is going to happen, an incident like this is going to occur, but if you feel like it's building up to that point it's better to have a plan in place." This plan can include identifying safe locations and escape routes, developing a network of trusted friends and family members who can provide support, and taking steps to increase one's physical safety.

Orders of protection can be obtained online and can be done without alerting the abuser. As Kate Thoene, Chief Strategy Officer at New Life Center, notes, "It can be done in any jurisdiction. If you don't want an abuser to know you're in Phoenix, you can get your order of protection in another jurisdiction."

Despite their benefits, orders of protection are not a guarantee of safety. As the mother of a domestic violence survivor recently told us, her daughter filed a protective order after being beaten by her ex-boyfriend Jamarr Young. However, when Young showed up at their home and assaulted her again, the order did not protect her or her family.

Experts emphasize that orders of protection are just one part of a comprehensive safety plan. As Perea notes, "At the end of the day an order of protection is just one part of a safety plan. There are times when people even with an order of protection even find themselves in harm's way."

Survivors of domestic violence deserve access to a range of support services and resources. The National Domestic Violence Hotline is available 24/7 at 1-800-799-SAFE (7233), or by texting "Start" to 88788.

In addition to the hotline, survivors can find help through local organizations such as the City Of Phoenix Family Advocacy Center and New Life Center. These organizations offer a range of services, including counseling, advocacy, and emergency assistance.

Ultimately, creating a comprehensive safety plan requires a combination of preparation, resourcefulness, and access to support. As Thoene notes, "It's not for everyone and it's not for every situation. At New Life Center we really feel the survivor is the expert of their own life and they will know if it will provoke or if it will be a safer environment if an order of protection is served."

articles.title: Retirement Income Shortfall Leads Boomers to Multigenerational Living Arrangements
articles.content:
As the retirement landscape continues to shift, many Baby Boomers are facing a harsh reality: they haven't saved enough for their golden years. A growing number of older adults are turning to an unconventional solution - moving in with their grown children. This trend, known as multigenerational living, is on the rise due to the mismatch between retirement income and living expenses.

According to Shane Stevenson from Winston & Companies Retirement and Financial Services, the average median retirement income for Baby Boomers today stands at $202,000. However, this amount may not go far in covering annual expenses of around $51,000. This disparity has led many retirees to consider alternative housing arrangements.

One such arrangement is multigenerational living, where older adults move in with their grown children to split costs and share responsibilities. This setup can be financially beneficial for all parties involved. Grandparents, in particular, are often able to assist with childcare, significantly reducing the burden of daycare and babysitting expenses.

A recent Pew Research Center study found that the number of people living in multigenerational homes has quadrupled since 1971, with nearly 60 million individuals now sharing households. While this trend is largely driven by adult children returning to live with their parents (the "boomerang effect"), there's also an increase in reverse boomerangs, where grown children are the head of the household and share a home with a parent.

As more individuals consider this unconventional living arrangement, it's essential to establish clear guidelines for sharing expenses and responsibilities. Stevenson advises creating a budget and contracts to ensure that all parties are comfortable with their roles and expectations.

For retirees and soon-to-be retirees, saving is crucial. Stevenson recommends reviewing assets, taking advantage of employer-matched retirement funds, and optimizing investments to boost the retirement nest egg.

Meanwhile, younger generations have time on their side. It's essential for them to start saving as soon as possible to take full advantage of compound interest and ensure a comfortable retirement.

As the retirement landscape continues to evolve, it's clear that Boomers are turning to innovative solutions to make ends meet. While multigenerational living may not be the traditional approach, it can provide a practical and financially savvy way for older adults to navigate their golden years.

On the other hand, home prices are not expected to come down anytime soon. This is due to a housing shortage, which has been exacerbated by increased new homebuilding in the market.

"There's absolutely nothing that would suggest prices are going to come down," Court said. "We still have a housing shortage, and the new homebuilding market is actually doing really well - we're building 25% more homes this year compared to last year."

articles.title: Florida NIL Drama Exposed: Rashada Sues Coach and Booster for Breach of Contract
articles.content:
The ongoing saga surrounding the name, image, and likeness (NIL) deal between former Arizona State quarterback Jaden Rashada and Florida Gators coach Billy Napier has taken a dramatic turn with the filing of a lawsuit. Rashada is seeking damages of at least $10 million from Napier, booster Hugh Hathcock, and several other defendants for what he claims was a failed NIL deal worth nearly $14 million.

According to the lawsuit filed in U.S. District Court in Pensacola, Rashada initially agreed to play for Miami in the fall of 2022, but was lured away by Napier and Hathcock with an NIL deal worth $13.85 million. The suit alleges that Napier vouched for the collective and promised Rashada would receive $1 million on signing day.

However, before Rashada could arrive on Florida's campus, the contract was terminated - suddenly and without warning. The lawsuit claims that the defendants engaged in fraudulent misrepresentation and inducement, aiding and abetting fraud, civil conspiracy to commit fraud, and other wrongdoing.

Rashada's attorney, Rusty Hardin, stated that this type of fraud is becoming more common in the college NIL landscape. "Wealthy alumni are taking advantage of young people by offering them life-changing sums of money, only to renege on their commitments," he said.

The lawsuit includes text messages that allegedly document fraudulent promises and inducements, including one message stating, "we look forward to setting him [Rashada] up for life."

Florida had been under NCAA investigation since last June regarding Rashada's recruitment. The NCAA asked the school not to conduct its own investigation and said it would notify the institution soon regarding the projected timeline of the investigation.

However, in March, the NCAA halted investigations into booster-backed collectives or other third parties making NIL compensation deals with Division I athletes. This development has put Florida back in the spotlight, at least.

Rashada initially agreed to play for Miami, but was lured away by Napier and Hathcock with an NIL deal worth $13.85 million. He later signed with his father's alma mater, Arizona State, before landing at Florida's biggest rival, Georgia.

The bombshell came a little more than two months after Rashada switched his verbal commitment from Miami to Florida. Rashada, his representatives, and the Gator Collective had presumably agreed to terms on the lucrative deal at the time of his flip.

The Gator Collective has since been disbanded. Other defendants include Marcus Castro-Walker, the school's former director of player engagement and NIL, and Velocity Automotive Solutions LLC, which was owned by Hathcock and was slated to provide most of the funding for Rashada's deal.

This is not a typical situation where a college athlete sues their coach or program. It highlights the complexity and challenges that arise when it comes to name, image, and likeness deals in college sports.

articles.title: Prescott Husband Sentenced to Life Without Parole for Burying Wife Alive Seven Years Ago
articles.content:
David Pagniano, the Prescott husband who pleaded guilty to murdering his wife Sandra in 2017, was sentenced to life in prison without the possibility of parole. The sentence came after Pagniano buried his wife alive at their home, with evidence showing she was likely conscious for up to five minutes after being buried.

According to Yavapai County Sheriff Sergeant Jack Mattox, the case began when Sandra went missing from her home while her young children and Pagniano were inside. However, it wasn't until one of Sandra's friends called in a missing persons report that authorities became involved. Initially, Pagniano had not reported his wife missing, but instead produced two handwritten notes claiming she had left him.

An investigation revealed that the handwriting analysis showed the notes were actually written by Pagniano himself, and further evidence gathered from his cell phone placed him at the location where Sandra's body would later be found. The evidence also showed that Sandra was bound around her mouth and head to prevent her from making any noise, and she was alive when she was buried.

Pagniano was initially charged with first-degree murder and faced the possibility of a death penalty. However, he decided to plead guilty just before his trial was set to begin, allowing the judge to determine his fate. The sentence handed down was life in prison without parole, as well as an additional 16 and a half years for kidnapping Sandra, forging the notes, and fraud schemes.

Mattox believes that Pagniano's decision to plead guilty spared their children from having to relive the details of their mother's murder during the trial. Despite the justice being served, Mattox acknowledged that certain cases can stick with you forever, leaving a lasting impact on those involved in the investigation.

Pagniano will spend the rest of his life behind bars, serving out his sentence and eventually passing away without the possibility of parole.

The indictment confirms that all defendants are facing charges for fraud, forgery, and conspiracy, which are all felonies.

According to the indictment, Giuliani "pressured" Arizona legislators and the Maricopa County Board of Supervisors to change the outcome of Arizona's election and was responsible for encouraging Republican electors in Arizona and six other contested states to vote for Trump. The indictment also alleges that Giuliani was involved in a scheme to use fake documents to persuade Congress not to certify Biden's victory.

Mark Meadows, Trump's former chief of staff, is among those who have been indicted in the case. Neither Meadows nor Giuliani were named in the redacted grand jury indictment released earlier because they had not been served with it, but they were readily identifiable based on descriptions in the document.

Arizona becomes the fourth state where allies of the former president have been charged with using false or unproven claims about voter fraud related to the election. Giuliani faces other legal proceedings, including a bankruptcy case and an indictment in Georgia, where he is accused of spearheading Trump's efforts to compel state lawmakers to ignore the will of voters and illegally appoint pro-Trump electoral college electors.

Among the defendants are 11 Arizona Republicans who submitted a document to Congress falsely declaring that Trump won in Arizona in the 2020 presidential election. The other defendants include Mike Roman, who was Trump's director of Election Day operations, and four attorneys accused of organizing an attempt to use fake documents to persuade Congress not to certify Biden's victory.

Trump himself was not charged but was referred to as an unindicted co-conspirator. The indictment names the following individuals as defendants: Rudolph Giuliani, Mark Meadows, John Eastman, Boris Epshteyn, Christina Bobb, Jenna Ellis, Michael Roman, Kelli Ward, Tyler Bowyer, Nancy Cottle, Jacob Hoffman, Anthony Kern, James Lamon, Robert Montgomery, Samuel Moorhead, Lorraine Pellegrino, Gregory Safsten, and Michael Ward.

The Arizona indictment said Eastman encouraged the GOP electors to cast their votes in December 2020, unsuccessfully pressured state lawmakers to change the election's outcome in Arizona, and told then-Vice President Mike Pence that he could reject Democratic electors in the counting of electoral votes in Congress on January 6, 2021.

A total of 12 people are scheduled for arraignment May 21, including nine of the 11 Republicans who had submitted a document to Congress falsely declaring Trump had won Arizona.

Arizona has one of the highest rates of domestic violence in the country, with 42.6% of women and 33.4% of men experiencing some form of abuse or stalking from their intimate partner. According to the Maricopa County Attorney's Office, domestic violence affects millions of people each year. In the United States alone, 20 people per minute are physically abused by their intimate partner, which translates to around 10 million victims annually. Furthermore, one in three women and one in 20 men are killed by their intimate partner.

Recent events have highlighted the severity of this issue. Just this week, a woman was held hostage by her baby's father in Surprise, Arizona. She managed to escape with minor injuries, but her baby was shot multiple times and is currently receiving medical attention at a local hospital. The house was then engulfed in flames, leaving authorities unsure of the suspect's current condition.

Tragedy has also struck in Gilbert, where 28-year-old Brooke Lundy was killed by her boyfriend, Matthew Blevins. Lundy's family reported that her boyfriend was controlling and abusive, having installed cameras in their home and threatening to harm them if she left him.

Domestic violence can take many forms, including physical, emotional, and financial abuse. Each situation is unique, making it challenging to identify the signs of an abusive relationship. However, there are organizations available to provide support and assistance to those affected by domestic violence.

In Maricopa County, several organizations offer resources for victims of domestic violence. The list below provides information on these programs and shelters:

One local resident shared their experience with Arizona's Family, stating that the detour signs were a source of confusion and inconvenience. ADOT has since confirmed that the signs were mistakenly placed and are being removed as quickly as possible.

This is not the first weekend that construction on I-17 has caused significant traffic issues for those living in the area. Last weekend, drivers faced hours-long backups, prompting ADOT to take steps to improve conditions during weekend closures.

In an effort to alleviate traffic congestion, ADOT recommends avoiding Sonoran Desert Drive and North Valley Parkway and instead utilizing the I-17 northbound frontage road as a detour.

The I-17 northbound between Loop 303 and SR-74 will remain closed until Monday at 5:00 a.m. Arizona's Family has a reporter on the ground, working to bring you updates as more information becomes available.

In the meantime, residents are encouraged to seek alternative routes and plan ahead for their weekend commutes. This ongoing construction project aims to improve traffic flow and reduce congestion in the area.

As this situation continues to evolve, Arizona's Family will continue to provide updates and keep readers informed about any changes or developments.

articles.title: Phoenix Chicken Ordinance Wins Approval: Backyard Fowl Get Green Light Across Arizona
articles.content:
The bill, HB 2325, has cleared the governor's desk and is poised to become law, allowing single-family homes in Arizona cities to keep their own backyard chickens. This development has been met with enthusiasm from chicken enthusiasts like Salih Alramahui, who has been raising chickens in his Phoenix backyard for years.

"I love them," Alramahui said of his feathered friends. "They're good for my family; my kids love them." With the bill's passage, Alramahui and others will be able to enjoy the benefits of raising their own chickens without worrying about local ordinances getting in the way.

Under the proposed law, residents would be allowed to keep hens (female chickens) in their backyards as long as they adhere to certain guidelines. These regulations include no roosters, an enclosure for the chickens, a minimum distance of 20 feet from neighbors, and regular poop cleanup twice a week.

The bill's author, Rep. Kevin Payne, a Republican from Peoria, has been working tirelessly to get this legislation passed. "I feel good about it," he said. "I think it's a very reasonable bill." With the governor's signature pending, Payne is hopeful that the bill will become law and allow Arizonans to enjoy the benefits of backyard chickens.

While some may worry about potential drawbacks, such as noise or smell, proponents argue that well-maintained chicken coops can be a source of pride and a way to reduce one's carbon footprint. Alramahui is among those who believe that allowing backyard chickens will have a positive impact on the community.

"It's beautiful," he said. "It's good for the people of Arizona." If signed into law, HB 2325 would mark a significant victory for chicken enthusiasts and those looking to live more sustainably in their communities.

As the bill awaits its fate, chicken keepers across Arizona are eagerly anticipating the opportunity to bring some egg-cellent news to their neighborhoods. With the governor's signature pending, it seems that backyard chickens may soon be the new normal in the Grand Canyon State.

In related news, local farmers' markets and community gardens may see an influx of fresh eggs and artisanal products as residents take advantage of this newfound freedom. For those looking to join the flock, there are already online forums and social media groups dedicated to sharing tips and advice on keeping backyard chickens.

As the debate rages on about the merits and drawbacks of backyard chickens, one thing is clear: this issue has captured the hearts and minds of many Arizonans. With the governor's decision pending, only time will tell if HB 2325 will become law and allow residents to keep their own backyard fowl.

In the meantime, proponents are urging Governor Katie Hobbs to sign the bill into law, citing its potential benefits for the community and the environment. As one chicken enthusiast put it, "It's good for the people of Arizona." Only time will tell if this sentiment will be echoed in the governor's decision.

articles.title: Phoenix Man Arrested After Fatal Crash, Domestic Violence Incident
articles.content:
A 33-year-old man was taken into custody after allegedly hitting and killing a bicyclist while fleeing from law enforcement in Phoenix on Thursday evening. The incident began with a domestic violence call near 16th Street and Southern Avenue around 8 p.m., where officers arrived to find Jamarr Young "immediately aggressive toward officers."

Young reportedly refused to comply with the officers' commands, using less-lethal tools to try and get him to stop. However, he then got into his car, drove it towards the officers, and hit a police SUV before speeding off. As he was heading northbound on 16th Street, Young struck a bicyclist who was crossing the road, but continued driving without stopping.

Emergency crews attempted to save the bicyclist, but unfortunately, he died at the scene. According to court documents, at the time of the crash, Young was speeding at 58 miles per hour in a 40-mile-per-hour zone and had a blood alcohol content (BAC) of 0.138, nearly double the legal limit.

Young was booked on 11 charges, including murder, leaving the scene of an accident with injuries, aggravated DUI, and multiple counts of aggravated assault on a police officer. The investigation into the domestic violence incident revealed that Young had previously assaulted his ex-partner in Flagstaff on May 1, just days before the Phoenix incident.

The victim involved in the domestic violence incident told investigators that Young showed up uninvited to her sister's home in Phoenix and became aggressive when she tried to leave. He allegedly slapped her and dumped a bottle of alcohol on her, prompting authorities to be called.

One officer broke his hand during the struggle with Young, while another suffered multiple cuts and bruises. The bicyclist who was killed has not been publicly identified, and the investigation into the crash is ongoing.

Young's arrest comes after a lengthy pursuit involving law enforcement, which was eventually called off due to the erratic nature of his driving. He attempted to flee on foot after crashing his car but was eventually apprehended by police.

articles.title: Arizona Naloxone Milestone Marks Ongoing Opioid Crisis Struggle
articles.content:
As the one-millionth dose of naloxone is handed out in Arizona, it's clear that the opioid crisis continues to plague the state and the nation as a whole. Sonoran Prevention Works (SPW) has been at the forefront of providing this life-saving medication since 2017.

According to SPW Executive Director Haley Coles, the organization has tracked the doses given out and reports nearly 30,000 lives saved due to the naloxone provided. While this milestone is a testament to the effectiveness of the medication, it's also a sobering reminder that there is still much work to be done.

The need for naloxone has grown over the years, with SPW citing nearly 30,000 people who have been given the drug as a direct result of their prevention efforts. Coles notes that while this success is crucial in saving lives, it's also a sign of a broader failure – a failure to prevent opioid overdoses from occurring in the first place.

As such, SPW is calling for better policies and education to help curb the opioid crisis. Coles believes that by working together as a community, we can make a significant impact on reducing overdose fatalities.

"We'd love to live in a world where naloxone isn't needed and people aren't experiencing overdoses in the first place," Coles says. "While we may not be able to eliminate drug use altogether, we can certainly do better."

Arizona's opioid fatality numbers have remained stable since 2021, unlike some other states. However, there is still more work to be done to prevent overdose deaths.

"It's going to take everybody – prevention, treatment, recovery, public health – everyone making an impact because it's not just one solution," Coles emphasizes.

To that end, SPW offers free kits of naloxone at events and will also mail them out to those who are at risk of an overdose. Coles recommends targeting people who are at risk of overdosing, as well as their family members, friends, or caregivers.

For more information on getting naloxone or learning how you can help prevent opioid overdoses, click here.

articles.title: Power Outages May Persist for Weeks in Parts of Houston
articles.content:
The storm that tore through Houston on Thursday has left nearly one million homes and businesses without power, with crews working to restore electricity but warning it could take weeks to fully recover.

Harris County Judge Lina Hidalgo said crews are still assessing the damage and determining the extent of the destruction caused by the severe thunderstorms. According to the National Weather Service, a tornado touched down near Cypress in Harris County with peak winds of 110 mph.

The storm has had far-reaching consequences, with school districts across the Houston area canceling classes for over 400,000 students and government offices closed. City officials are urging people to avoid downtown and stay off roads, many of which are flooded or lined with downed power lines and malfunctioning traffic lights.

At least 2,500 traffic lights are out, according to Mayor Sylvester Turner's office, which has also warned would-be looters that police are out in force, including 50 state troopers sent to the area to prevent looting. Two of the deaths were caused by falling trees, and another occurred when a crane blew over in strong winds.

President Joe Biden has issued a disaster declaration for seven counties in Texas, including Harris, due to severe weather since April 26. The declaration makes federal funding available to people affected by the storms.

The storm's impact extends beyond Houston, with neighboring Montgomery County describing damage to transmission lines as "catastrophic." High-voltage transmission towers were torn apart and downed power lines pose a challenge for utility companies, according to Alexandria von Meier, a power and energy expert.

"It's more typical that the damage is just at the distribution system, which is, you know, just not as strong," von Meier said. "Because if you try to fix this kind of thing in a hurry and you try to restore power in a hurry, you might injure people. You would be putting the workers at risk. You could be putting other people at risk."

The storms also aren't over yet, with Gulf Coast states expected to experience scattered, severe thunderstorms with tornadoes, large hail, and damaging winds through Saturday. Heavy rainfall is possible for eastern Louisiana into central Alabama.

In the meantime, residents are advised to stay safe by avoiding flooded areas, staying away from downed power lines, and following evacuation orders if necessary.

articles.title: Trump Ally Pleads Not Guilty in Arizona Election Conspiracy Case
articles.content:
As the investigation into the attempts to overturn the 2020 presidential election continues, attorney John Eastman has pleaded not guilty to conspiracy, fraud, and forgery charges related to his role in the effort to persuade Congress not to certify Joe Biden's win in Arizona. Eastman is the first individual charged in the state's fake elector case to be arraigned.

The indictment alleges that Eastman encouraged the Republican electors to cast their votes in December 2020, attempted to pressure state lawmakers to change the election's outcome, and told then-Vice President Mike Pence that he could reject Democratic electors in the counting of electoral votes on January 6, 2021. Eastman is also accused of devising a strategy to try to persuade Congress not to certify the election.

The charges against Eastman stem from an investigation into the efforts of Trump allies to submit false documents claiming Donald Trump had won Arizona's presidential election. The indictment notes that Biden ultimately won Arizona by more than 10,000 votes.

Twelve other individuals charged in the case, including nine of the 11 Republicans who submitted the fake electoral certificates, are scheduled for arraignment on May 21. Charges against former New York mayor and Trump-aligned attorney Rudy Giuliani have not been publicly disclosed, but he is named as an unindicted co-conspirator in the indictment.

The Arizona investigation is part of a broader effort by authorities to hold accountable those who sought to undermine the democratic process. In total, four states – Arizona, Georgia, Michigan, and Wisconsin – have seen individuals charged with using false or unproven claims about voter fraud related to the 2020 election.

Eastman's plea comes after he was previously indicted on racketeering, conspiracy, and other charges in a scheme to overturn the 2020 presidential election in Georgia. He has pleaded not guilty to those charges as well.

The investigation into Trump's allies' efforts to undermine the election is ongoing, with multiple individuals facing charges related to their actions. The case serves as a reminder of the importance of upholding the integrity of the democratic process and holding accountable those who seek to subvert it.

In related news, former Trump chief of staff Mark Meadows is scheduled for arraignment on June 7.

articles.title: Memorial Day Travel Rush Expected to Hit Record Highs
articles.content:
As Memorial Day approaches, travelers in Arizona can expect a significant surge in road and air traffic. According to AAA, nearly one million Arizonans will be hitting the roads over the long weekend, with the highest number ever recorded.

"We're expecting a record 38.4 million people to travel by car over Memorial Day weekend, which is up four percent compared to last year," said Julian Paredes, spokesperson for AAA. "Thursday and Friday are going to be the busiest days, so it's essential to start your trip as early as possible. Get out the door and get on the road before 11 a.m."

The increased traffic is not limited to roads alone; airports are also expected to be crowded, with a projected 3.51 million air travelers. This marks the most crowded Memorial Day weekend at airports since 2005.

To prepare for the busy weekend, AAA recommends making sure your car is in top shape. "This is a great time to get your car serviced," Paredes said. "You want to check your tires, make sure there's enough tread. Make sure your car battery is ready, especially in Arizona where car batteries don't last as long."

Planning ahead is crucial for a stress-free travel experience. "Planning is really your best friend when it comes to Memorial Day," Paredes emphasized. "Things can get hectic. There will be a lot of people on the road. Lots of traffic. So, if you do plenty of planning, it can really spare you a big headache."

With so many travelers on the move, it's essential to prioritize your vehicle and travel plans. Make sure to check your car battery, tire tread, and overall condition before embarking on your journey.

To avoid any speed bumps, AAA suggests starting your trip early in the day, preferably before 11 a.m. This will give you a head start on potential traffic congestion.

Traveling by air? Be prepared for long lines and crowded airport terminals. Leave extra time to get to the airport, and consider checking in online or using mobile check-in services.

The key to a successful Memorial Day travel experience is planning ahead. With a little foresight and preparation, you can minimize stress and make the most of your weekend getaway.

As the holiday weekend approaches, travelers are advised to stay informed about traffic conditions and flight schedules through AAA's travel resources and updates.

In conclusion, with nearly one million Arizonans hitting the roads over Memorial Day, it's crucial to plan ahead, prepare your vehicle, and expect a busy travel season. By doing so, you'll be well on your way to a stress-free and enjoyable holiday weekend.

articles.title: Arizona Woman's Tragic Death Highlights Dangers of Domestic Violence
articles.content:
The tragic murder-suicide in Gilbert has left the community reeling, but the family of Brooke Lundy is still trying to come to terms with her death. The 28-year-old woman was killed by her boyfriend, Matthew Blevins, before he took his own life.

Lundy's family had only recently discovered that her boyfriend had a history of controlling and abusive behavior. They had been unaware of the extent of the abuse, which included cameras being installed around the house to monitor Lundy's every move.

"We were very, very close," said Lundy's uncle, Joey Christensen. "We just learned about this two weeks ago. It was like a bombshell."

Christensen and his mother-in-law, Judy Rosenburg, spoke on behalf of the family and expressed their shock and helplessness at Lundy's death.

"They all feel helpless," said Rosenburg. "We're still trying to process everything that happened."

The investigation into Lundy's death is ongoing, but police believe she was shot multiple times before Blevins took his own life.

Lundy grew up in Nebraska and had a difficult childhood, having lost her father to suicide at the age of 12. Her mother was unable to care for her, and she eventually moved in with her grandparents and Christensen. She lost both of her grandparents by the time she was 14.

Despite these challenges, Lundy was determined to make a fresh start in Arizona. She met Blevins while working at a gas station, and they eventually moved in together. However, it wasn't until recently that her family discovered the extent of his abuse.

Rosenburg said that Lundy had told her family about the abuse just two weeks before her death, revealing that Blevins had broken her nose and arm and threatened to harm her whole family if she left him.

Lundy's family is now working to raise awareness about domestic violence and the dangers it poses. They have set up a GoFundMe page to help cover funeral expenses and are encouraging others to seek help if they or someone they know is in a similar situation.

The Domestic Violence Hotline is available 24/7 at 1-800-799-SAFE (7233) or by texting "START" to 88788.

articles.title: Desert Burial Sentence: Life Without Parole for Pagniano
articles.content:
The trial that had captivated the nation's attention came to an end as David Michael Pagniano was sentenced to life in prison without the possibility of parole for the heinous crime of burying his wife, Sandra, alive. The 62-year-old defendant had opted to plead guilty just a day before the trial, leaving the court with no choice but to impose a sentence that reflected the gravity of his actions.

According to the Yavapai County Sheriff's Office, Pagniano's crime was committed in 2017 when Sandra mysteriously disappeared as she and her husband were going through a divorce. A massive manhunt ensued, and authorities eventually discovered Sandra's body bound and gagged in packing tape inside a hand-dug grave in a rural area north of Prescott.

The investigation revealed that Pagniano had abducted his wife as her children slept, binding her with packing tape. He then drove to a remote area and buried her alive. Evidence showed that Sandra vigorously struggled while she was in the grave, and it's possible she may have been conscious for up to five minutes before succumbing to her fate.

Cellphone evidence also placed Pagniano at the gravesite on multiple occasions, including days before Sandra went missing and the night of the kidnapping. Detectives discovered notes that appeared to be written by Sandra, stating that she was leaving and giving her husband her vehicles, house, and custody of their children. However, these notes were actually fabricated by Pagniano himself.

In addition to the life sentence, Pagniano was given an additional 16.5 years in prison for kidnapping, forgery, and fraud schemes. Yavapai County Attorney Dennis McGrane stated that his office had pursued the death penalty due to the horrific nature of the crime, but ultimately decided against it when Pagniano opted to plead guilty.

Pagniano's lawyer was unavailable for comment, but sources close to the case revealed that the defendant had shown no remorse during the sentencing hearing. The victim's family has spoken out about the devastating impact of Pagniano's actions and has expressed hope that the life sentence will bring some closure to their tragedy.

As news of the sentencing spreads, communities across Arizona are left grappling with the brutality of Pagniano's crime and the senseless loss of life that it has brought. The case serves as a stark reminder of the importance of justice and the need for society to hold accountable those who commit such heinous crimes.

articles.title: Arizona Highway Tragedy Claims Lives of Two Amazon Workers
articles.content:
The tragic incident that unfolded on Interstate 10 near Tonopah, Arizona, has left the community in shock and mourning. Early Thursday afternoon, a semi-truck carrying two Amazon workers collided with an overpass bridge, resulting in the deaths of both individuals.

According to authorities, the accident occurred just before 2 p.m. in the eastbound lanes of I-10 near 339th Avenue. The investigation suggests that the driver may have experienced a tire blowout, causing them to lose control and strike the center column of the bridge. The semi-truck came to rest in the median.

Tragically, two people were on board the truck at the time of the accident. One individual was pronounced dead at the scene, while the other succumbed to their injuries later at a hospital. The victims have been identified as Abdullahi Muhammed Abdi, 40, from Colorado, and Fadhi Hamdi Ali, 35, from Minnesota.

Amazon officials released a statement expressing their condolences to the families of the victims, stating, "We're incredibly saddened to learn of this tragic accident, and our thoughts are with the victims' families and loved ones during this difficult time. We're working to learn more information and will continue to support local law enforcement as they investigate."

The eastbound lanes of I-10 were closed for several hours following the incident, causing significant traffic disruptions in the area.

Despite the severity of the accident, authorities have deemed the bridge safe for traffic, with only minor damage reported. The Arizona Department of Transportation (ADOT) and bridge engineers conducted a thorough inspection to ensure public safety.

As the community comes together to mourn the loss of these two lives, it is essential that we prioritize road safety and take necessary precautions to prevent such tragedies from occurring in the future.

In related news, authorities are urging motorists to exercise caution on our highways and to report any concerns or issues they may have regarding road conditions. Furthermore, drivers are advised to maintain a safe distance and be aware of their surroundings at all times.

The incident serves as a poignant reminder of the importance of highway safety and the devastating consequences that can result from accidents. As we navigate this difficult time, it is crucial that we prioritize public safety and work together to prevent such tragedies from occurring in the future.

articles.title: Phoenix Girl Found Safe After Day-Long Search
articles.content:

articles.title: National Drowning Rates Rise for First Time in Decades: Experts Urge Vigilance, Swim Lessons Amid Summer Vacation Plans
articles.content:
As the summer season approaches, experts are sounding the alarm about a disturbing trend: national drowning rates have risen for the first time in decades. According to a new report from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), over 4,500 drowning deaths occurred each year from 2020-2022, marking a concerning increase.

This alarming statistic is especially pertinent when considering that almost 40 million U.S. adults cannot swim. Furthermore, drowning remains the leading cause of death among children ages one to four, and the second-leading cause of accidental death for children between five and 14.

A closer examination of the data reveals a shocking finding: nine out of ten drowning deaths occur when a caregiver is supervising but not paying attention. This emphasizes the importance of vigilance and active supervision during pool, beach, or lake activities.

To mitigate this risk, the United States Swim School Association (USSSA) recommends taking several precautions. These include having enough U.S. Coast Guard-approved life jackets for family and guests, avoiding arm floaties, keeping toys away from the pool, and designating a "pool watcher" to monitor kids swimming, especially at parties.

However, USSSA Executive Director Liza Zarda stresses that the biggest line of defense against drowning is swim lessons. She notes that these lessons reduce the risk of drowning by 88%, and many programs offer grant and scholarship opportunities.

For families seeking swim lessons near them, Zarda advises checking with their city's parks and recreation programs for classes. Alternatively, individuals can find certified swim schools in their area through USSSA's website.

As the summer season approaches, it is crucial that we take proactive measures to ensure our loved ones' safety around water. By staying informed, taking necessary precautions, and prioritizing swim lessons, we can work together to reduce the risk of drowning and create a safer environment for everyone.
